headline: Heard on the Street Recap: Trump’s New Deal
summary: President Trump said he wants to do more deals like the government’s equity investment in Intel, which he posited as a new way of doing industrial policy.  The U.S. converted funds previously allocated for manufacturing expansion under a 2022 statute into a 9.9% stake in the chip maker.  The government also got a five-year warrant under which it could get another 5% if Intel spins out or sells off its manufacturing operations.

The U.S. converted funds previously allocated for manufacturing expansion under a 2022 statute into a 9.9% stake in the chip maker.  The government also got a five-year warrant under which it could get another 5% if Intel spins out or sells off its manufacturing operations.

headline: US doesn't need a sovereign wealth fund, market expert says
summary: STORY: The federal government could take stakes in other U.S. semiconductor companies or even move to other industries, White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett told CNBC in an interview on Monday following its stake in Intel."The president has made it clear all the way back to the campaign that he thinks that, in the end, it would be great if the U.S. could start to build up a sovereign wealth fund. And so I'm sure that at some point there'll be more transactions, if not in this industry in other industries," Hassett said.But Miller thinks the move would be inappropriate and unnecessary."When you think about other countries with sovereign funds, it makes me think of countries where the sovereign fund is almost meant to reflect confidence in countries and in companies that might not have worldwide support," she said. "So it's a little surprising to me because U.S. companies are looked on so strongly, and they are independent and they have respect worldwide."

raw.headline: US doesn't need a sovereign wealth fund, market expert says
raw.summary: STORY: The federal government could take stakes in other U.S. semiconductor companies or even move to other industries, White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett told CNBC in an interview on Monday following its stake in Intel."The president has made it clear all the way back to the campaign that he thinks that, in the end, it would be great if the U.S. could start to build up a sovereign wealth fund. And so I'm sure that at some point there'll be more transactions, if not in this industry in other industries," Hassett said.But Miller thinks the move would be inappropriate and unnecessary."When you think about other countries with sovereign funds, it makes me think of countries where the sovereign fund is almost meant to reflect confidence in countries and in companies that might not have worldwide support," she said. "So it's a little surprising to me because U.S. companies are looked on so strongly, and they are independent and they have respect worldwide."

headline: U.S. Could Take Stakes in More Companies, Hassett Says
summary: The U.S. could take further stakes in companies similar to its equity investment in Intel, a top White House economic adviser said.  Kevin Hassett, President Trump’s National Economic Council director, said on CNBC Monday that further deals could form part of Trump’s plan to set up a U.S. sovereign wealth fund.  “I’m sure that at some point there’ll be more transactions, if not in this industry, in other industries,” Hassett said.

headline: Trump says he will continue to make deals like Intel one
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -U.S. President Donald Trump on Monday said he would make deals with other companies similar to the one he announced last week with Intel.  Trump on Friday said the U.S. would take a 10% stake in Intel under a deal with the struggling chipmaker that converts government grants into an equity share.  "I will make deals like that for our Country all day long," Trump said in a post on Truth Social.

headline: Trump’s Intel Move Blurs Party Lines on Economic Intervention
summary: President  Trump’s  latest economic move has drawn outrage from conservatives—and praise from some on the left—in the latest example of the odd bedfellows created by his idiosyncratic worldview.  The announcement last week that the government plans to take a 10% stake in the troubled U.S. chip maker  Intel  prompted an outpouring of criticism from voices on the right, who accuse the administration of nationalizing industry.  “Today it’s Intel, tomorrow it could be any industry,” Sen.  Rand Paul  (R., Ky.) said Friday.

raw.headline: Trump’s Intel Move Blurs Party Lines on Economic Intervention
raw.summary: President  Trump’s  latest economic move has drawn outrage from conservatives—and praise from some on the left—in the latest example of the odd bedfellows created by his idiosyncratic worldview.  The announcement last week that the government plans to take a 10% stake in the troubled U.S. chip maker  Intel  prompted an outpouring of criticism from voices on the right, who accuse the administration of nationalizing industry.  “Today it’s Intel, tomorrow it could be any industry,” Sen.  Rand Paul  (R., Ky.) said Friday.

headline: Intel warns US stake could hurt international sales, future grants
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Intel said on Monday that the U.S. government's 9.9% stake in the chipmaker could pose risks to its business, from potentially harming international sales to limiting its ability to secure future government grants.  The company laid out new risk factors in a securities filing after the government decided to convert $11 billion in government grants into an equity stake in Intel, the latest extraordinary intervention in corporate America by President Donald Trump.  Separately, Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan said in a video posted on Monday by the Commerce Department that the company did not need the government funding.

raw.headline: Intel warns US stake could hurt international sales, future grants
raw.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Intel said on Monday that the U.S. government's 9.9% stake in the chipmaker could pose risks to its business, from potentially harming international sales to limiting its ability to secure future government grants.  The company laid out new risk factors in a securities filing after the government decided to convert $11 billion in government grants into an equity stake in Intel, the latest extraordinary intervention in corporate America by President Donald Trump.  Separately, Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan said in a video posted on Monday by the Commerce Department that the company did not need the government funding.

headline: White House's Hassett says US could take stakes in other chip companies
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The federal government could take stakes in other U.S. semiconductor companies or even move to other industries, White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett told CNBC in an interview on Monday following its stake in Intel.  Hassett, asked if the Intel deal was the start of a larger effort by the U.S. government to take equity stakes in other industries that it subsidizes, or other companies in the AI and chip space that are subsidized such as Advanced Micro Devices Inc or Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, said there could be other similar transactions.

raw.headline: White House's Hassett says US could take stakes in other chip companies
raw.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The federal government could take stakes in other U.S. semiconductor companies or even move to other industries, White House economic adviser Kevin Hassett told CNBC in an interview on Monday following its stake in Intel.  Hassett, asked if the Intel deal was the start of a larger effort by the U.S. government to take equity stakes in other industries that it subsidizes, or other companies in the AI and chip space that are subsidized such as Advanced Micro Devices Inc or Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, said there could be other similar transactions.
